questions.text: Match the following characteristic findings along with their disease causative agent:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A3 B4 C1 D2

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Nodular rash with indentation: This description is characteristic of poxvirus infections, such as chickenpox (varicella) and smallpox, where the lesions are often described as "dewdrop on a rose petal" for chickenpox, and with deep indentations for smallpox.

 

Option B: Koplik spots: These are small, white, grain-like spots found on the buccal mucosa opposite the first and second molars, and are pathognomonic for measles (Rubeola).

 

Option C: Forchheimer spots: These are pinpoint red spots seen on the soft palate, often associated with German measles (Rubella).

 

Option D: Pastia's lines: These are linear petechial rash found in the creases of the body, particularly in the antecubital fossa, and are associated with scarlet fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 6733

questions.text: Match the following Inclusion bodies and their infectious disease:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A2 B4 C3 D1

 

Option A: Henderson Patterson Bodies (A2): These inclusion bodies are characteristic of Molluscum Contagiosum. They are found within the cytoplasm of infected epithelial cells and are a diagnostic feature of the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Cowdry Type A (B4): Cowdry Type A inclusion bodies are typically associated with Herpes Simplex Virus infections. They are eosinophilic, intranuclear inclusions found in infected cells.

 

Option C: Cowdry Type B (C3): Though Cowdry Type B inclusions are specifically linked to Polio Virus.

 

Option D: Guarnieri Bodies (D1): Guarnieri bodies are pathognomonic of Small Pox infection caused by the Variola virus. They are eosinophilic or basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the cytoplasm of infected cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition

questions.text: A pediatrician evaluates a 5-year-old child who has been experiencing recurrent nosebleeds and easy bruising. Upon physical examination, the child has noticeable petechiae spread across various skin surfaces. Prolonged BT, while CT, PT, and aPTT are within normal ranges. The child's mother also mentions that the child's elder sister, Sana, exhibits similar symptoms, suggesting a potential hereditary pattern. Which genetic disorder should be considered in the differential diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bernard-Soulier syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Possible genetic disorders that should be considered in this case is Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

 

  • It is characterized by bleeding tendency along with Prolonged BT and normal CT and PT and aPTT.

  • It is caused by a defect in the GPIb-IX-V receptor complex on platelets.

  • This receptor complex is responsible for platelet adhesion and aggregation.

  • Treatment may involve platelet transfusions, medications that increase platelet counts, and measures to control bleeding.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome: This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, visual impairment, and a bleeding diathesis due to platelet dysfunction; however, it is typically associated with additional systemic symptoms.

 

Option C: Hemophilia A: This is an X-linked recessive disorder that primarily affects males and is characterized by deficiency of clotting factor VIII, which would result in abnormal PT and aPTT, not typically seen in this case.

 

Option D: Hemophilia B: Similar to Hemophilia A, Hemophilia B is also an X-linked recessive disorder affecting males with a deficiency of clotting factor IX, which also would not present with normal PT and aPTT levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by recurrent bleeding, and prolonged bleeding time, with normal coagulation studies, in a child with a family history of similar symptoms. This condition should be differentiated from other coagulopathies that present with abnormal clotting factor levels, such as Hemophilia A and B.


Ref; 21st edition nelson, page number 10,297

questions.text: A 5-days-old baby with intellectual disability, mongoloid slant of the eyes, sandal gap toes, and distinctive facial features consistent with Down syndrome presents to the clinic. The baby exhibits pallor and small petechiae, raising concern. Routine blood tests reveal an increased leukocyte count with the presence of blast cells, and further examination identifies hepatosplenomegaly. Given these findings in a baby with Down syndrome, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transient myeloproliferative disorder

 

Option A:

 

Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD) is a condition seen in newborns with Down syndrome and is characterized by an increased number of blast cells in the blood, hepatosplenomegaly, and increased white blood cell counts. TMD is unique to individuals with Down syndrome and typically resolves spontaneously within the first few months of life, although some cases may progress to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The presence of blast cells and the association with Down syndrome are key indicators for TMD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) are possible hematological malignancies in children with Down syndrome. However, the transient nature of the symptoms and the age of the child suggest TMD as the most likely initial diagnosis. It is important to monitor the child for potential progression to AML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transient myeloproliferative disorder is characterized by high leukocyte counts, blasts cells in peripheral blood with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly.

 

  • Resolves within first 3 months.

  • It has GATA 1 mutation.

  • Require monitoring (20% may develop acute myeloid leukemia by 3 years of age).

 

Ref; Ghai 9th edition – Page no – 600.

questions.text: A couple, after 17 years of marriage, welcomes a baby born with features indicative of Down syndrome. Due to residing in a rural area, the mother had not attended any prenatal visits and was unaware of the diagnosis until after the birth. Upon confirming the diagnosis of Down syndrome, you discuss the characteristics of the condition and potential future complications with the mother. Concerned about the association between Down syndrome and increased risk of hematological malignancies, the mother inquires about the most common type of blood cancer her child might be at risk for. How would you respond?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

 

Option A:

 

Children with Down syndrome have a higher risk of developing certain types of leukemia, with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) being the most common. Studies have shown that children with Down syndrome are at an increased risk for ALL compared to the general population. This risk factor is significant enough to warrant careful monitoring for signs of leukemia as the child grows.

 

The clinical features of Downs syndrome (trisomy 21) are:

 

  • Flat facial profile and an upward slant to the eye
  • Short neck
  • Abnormally shaped ears
  • White spots on the iris of the eye (Brushfield spots)
  • Single, deep transverse crease on the palm of the hand.

 

The most common leukemia in case of down syndrome is ALL, but most common myeloid origin leukemia is Acute megakaryoblasticleukemia, which is AML M7.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Chronic lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is much more common in adults and is rare in children, including those with Down syndrome.

 

Option C: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is also more common in adults and not typically associated with an increased risk in individuals with Down syndrome.

 

Option D: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) does occur at a higher rate in individuals with Down syndrome, particularly in the form of transient myeloproliferative disorder in newborns, which can progress to AML. However, ALL is still considered the most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The children with Down syndrome are at an elevated risk for Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) compared to the general pediatric population. This knowledge is important for guiding the clinical monitoring and care of children with Down syndrome to promptly identify and treat potential complications.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 610-615.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his mother due to a notable decrease in activity level compared to peers, along with easy fatigability and a tendency to bruise. Suspecting anemia, you order a complete blood count (CBC), which reveals an RBC count of 2.0 X 10^12/L, a WBC count of 55,000 per microliter, and a platelet count of 70,000 per microliter. Further examination shows lymphadenopathy and bone pain. Based on these clinical findings and laboratory results, what is the most likely diagnosis, and what is a known good prognostic factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia and hyper diploidy

 

Option A:

 

Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia:

 

  • Most common leukaemia in children.
  • Two types B-cell and T-cell ALL.
  • Clinical features include low-grade fever, fatigue, bone pain, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly
  • CBC shows anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Bone Marrow biopsy shows >25% of blast cells.

 

 

  • Treatment; Vincristine and Corticosteroid for 2-3 years.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Chronic lymphoblastic leukaemia (CLL) and female gender: CLL is rare in children and typically occurs in older adults. Gender is not a significant prognostic factor in CLL.

 

Option C: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and hypodiploidy: Hypodiploidy, or fewer chromosomes than normal, is generally associated with a poorer prognosis in ALL.

 

Option D: Chronic lymphoblastic leukaemia (CLL) and male gender: As mentioned, CLL is uncommon in children, and male gender is not known to be a significant prognostic factor in CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings of low RBC count, high WBC count with lymphadenopathy, bone pain, and easy bruising and fatigability are indicative of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (ALL), a common childhood leukaemia. Hyper diploidy, or the presence of more than the normal number of chromosomes in leukemic cells, is considered a good prognostic factor in ALL, associated with a better response to treatment and improved outcomes.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4830-4832.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a 3-year-old child with distinctive facial features, including a mongoloid slant of eyes and what appears to be gingival hyperplasia, is brought in by his mother due to recurrent nosebleeds and general fatigue. Upon examination, the child also exhibits intellectual disability and characteristic sandal gap toes. A complete blood count reveals anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with a predominance of 75% blast cells. Considering the child's physical presentation and blood findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute myeloid leukemia

 

Option A:

 

The clinical findings of anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis and gingival hypertrophy is seen in case of Acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Other clinical features include,

 

  • Fatigue, weakness, fever and weight loss, are non-specific
  • Granulocytopenia, thrombocytopenia and anemia
  • Infection of skin, mucous membranes, gums, respiratory,
  • The prevalence and degree of organ infiltration vary somewhat with the different types of leukemia
  • Abdominal fullness (enlargement of the liver and spleen)
  • Gum hypertrophy (aml-m4 and m5)
  • Bone and joint pain, tenderness
  • Neurological symptoms: headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, cranial nerve dysfunction (AML-M4 and M5)
  • DIC (AML-M3)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: In case of Acute lymphoblastic leukemia, anemia and thrombocytopenia are seen and is most common leukemia in children but it is not associated with gum hypertrophy.


Option C: Hodgkins Lymphoma presents with continuous lymph node involvement and is not associated with gum hypertrophy.

 

Option D: Chronic myeloid leukemia, anemia and thrombocytopenia are seen but is most prevalent in elderly patients and is not associated with gum hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of distinctive facial features consistent with Down syndrome, recurrent bleeding, fatigue, and the CBC findings of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and high blast cell count is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML is more common in children with Down syndrome, and the specific clinical presentation of gingival hyperplasia can be associated with the monocytic subtypes of AML, such as acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AMML) or acute monoblastic leukemia (AMoL), also classified as M4 or M5 in the French American-British (FAB) classification, respectively.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4832

questions.text: A 34-year-old mother brought her 2-month-old infant to your pediatric clinic, who reports that the baby developed a fever on Sunday, followed by the eruption of a distinctive rash on Friday. The mother is concerned and suspects that the rash might be related to her sister-in-law, who frequently kisses the child on the cheeks and playfully pinches and slaps him. Upon examination, the child presents with bright red erythema on both cheeks, giving a "slapped" appearance, without significant involvement of the nasal bridge and circumoral region. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slapped Cheek appearance

 

Option B:

 

Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped cheek syndrome, is a viral infection caused by the human parvovirus B19. It is most common in children but can affect people of all ages.

 

  • The first symptoms of Erythema infectiosum (The fifth disease) include fever, headache, and muscle aches.
  • Within a few days, a rash appears on the face, giving it a "slapped cheek" appearance. The rash may spread to the arms, legs, and trunk.
  • The rash is usually not itchy, but some people may experience joint pain and swelling, particularly in adults.
  • The rash may last for several weeks, but it usually goes away on its own without any complications.

 

Treatment: There is no specific treatment for Erythema infectiosum, as it is a viral infection (Parvovirus B19). Treatment is usually focused on relieving symptoms, such as fever and joint pain, with over-the-counter pain relievers and anti-inflammatory medications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Kissing disease: Also known as infectious mononucleosis, it is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). It typically presents with fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy, not primarily with a cheek rash.

 

Option C: Battered baby syndrome: This term refers to physical abuse of infants, leading to multiple injuries. The described scenario and rash do not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option D: Juvenile SLE: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) can affect children, but the classic malar rash associated with SLE spares the nasolabial folds, which is different from the described presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Slapped Cheek" appearance is characteristic of Parvovirus B19 infection, also known as erythema infectiosum or Fifth disease; commonly affects children and presents with a distinctive facial rash that resembles the appearance as if the cheeks have been slapped. The rash can subsequently spread to the body, forming a lacy pattern.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1570-1588

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 6-year-old child to the pediatric clinic with complaints of a spreading rash. The rash, characterized by small, itchy, fluid-filled blisters, started on the face and has now covered the trunk and limbs. Accompanying symptoms include fever and fatigue. Notably, the rash exhibits lesions at various stages of development. Given these symptoms, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Varicella

 

Option C:

 

The clinical features described in the case are typical of varicella or chickenpox.

  • Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection that is common in children.
  • The rash typically starts on the face and then spreads to the trunk and limbs, i.e., centripetal in distribution.
  • The rash consists of small, itchy, fluid-filled blisters that can be in different stages of development.
  • Characteristic Dew drops on rose petal appearance which represent the fluid filled blisters (dewdrops) on an erythematous base (rose petal).
  • The child may also have fever and fatigue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Impetigo, is a bacterial skin infection that typically presents with honey-colored crusts on the skin. It does not usually cause a rash consisting of fluid-filled blisters.

 

Option B: Measles, is a viral infection that can cause a rash, fever, and other symptoms. However, the rash in measles typically starts on the head and then spreads to the rest of the body. The rash consists of larger, flat, red spots that may merge together.

 

Option D: Hand, Foot and Mouth disease (HFMD) is a viral infection caused by coxsackie A16 virus that typically causes a rash on the hands, feet, and in the mouth. It does not usually cause a rash on other parts of the body.

 

Educational Objective
 

Fever accompanied by a pruritic (itchy) rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and limbs, with lesions in various stages of development (including fluid-filled blisters and crusted lesions), is highly indicative of Varicella, also known as chickenpox, which is caused by the Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 1579-1585.

questions.text: Match the following haematological conditions along with their inheritance pattern:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A3 B4 C1 D2

 

Option D:

 

  1. G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects the red blood cells and can lead to hemolytic anemia.

  2. Thalassemia is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the body's inability to produce normal amounts of hemoglobin.

  3. Hereditary spherocytosis is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and is characterized by the presence of spherocytes in the blood smear.

  4. AIHA (Autoimmune HemolyticAnemia) is not typically inherited but is an acquired condition in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition page 4837

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to a pediatric clinic by their mother due to the appearance of petechiae and a notable degree of pallor. The clinical signs raise suspicion for a microangiopathic hemolyticanemia. As the evaluation progresses, it becomes clear that the child is also suffering from severe acute renal failure. The child presents with neither fever nor neurological symptoms during the physical examination. Given the symptoms of petechiae, pallor indicative of hemolytic anemia, and acute renal failure without fever or neurological involvement, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemolytic-uremic syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Haemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) is similar to thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) in that it produces a micro-angiopathic haemolytic anaemia, but it is distinguished from TTP by the lack of neurologic symptoms and by the severe acute renal failure, which is manifested clinically by a markedly increased serum BUN.

 

  • Classic HUS is seen in children and is related to infection, usually acquired from contaminated ground meat, by verocytotoxin-producing Escherichia coli.
  • This toxin is similar to Shigella toxins, which, together with E. coli and viruses, are causes of the adult form of HUS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Autoimmune HemolyticAnemia: This typically does not include renal failure as a primary component.

 

Option B: Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy: DIC is a secondary condition that results from another underlying process and is often accompanied by bleeding and clotting simultaneously. It could show similar lab findings but is usually associated with an identifiable cause of widespread coagulation activation, such as sepsis or malignancy, and would typically present with fever if infectious in nature.

 

Option D: Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura: ITP primarily involves a low platelet count leading to bleeding manifestations and does not typically include hemolyticanemia or renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by the triad of microangiopathic hemolyticanemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. It often occurs after a gastrointestinal infection, particularly with strains of E. coli that produce Shiga toxin. The absence of fever or neurological manifestations helps to differentiate HUS from other similar conditions, such as thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which often includes neurological symptoms.

 

Ref; nelson 21st edition page 2718

questions.text: A concerned mother visits a pediatric clinic with her 5-year-old child, who has been suffering from fever and a rash for the past few days. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes the presence of fluid-filled vesicles and lesions at various stages of crusting. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of chickenpox is made. Which of the following statements about chickenpox is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The lesion start appearing on the palm & sole and spread to the face and scalp.

 

Option D:

 

Chicken pox:

 

  1. Varicella lesions often appear first on the scalp, face, or trunk.

  2. The causative organism responsible is varicella virus (HHV-3).

  3. Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection that is common in children.

  4. The initial exanthem consists of intensely pruritic erythematous macules that evolve through the papular stage to form clear, fluid-filled vesicles.

  5. The rash consists of small, itchy, fluid-filled blisters that can be in different stages of development.

  6. The child may also have fever and fatigue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chicken pox is caused by varicella zoster virus.

 

Option B: The initial exanthem consists of intensely pruritic erythematous macules that evolve through the papular stage to form clear, fluid-filled vesicles.

 

Option C: the simultaneous presence of lesions in various stages of evolution is characteristic of varicella

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, typically starts with lesions on the face, scalp, and trunk, spreading outward to the limbs, not starting from the palms and soles. The lesions can indeed be pruritic (itchy), and one of the hallmark features of chickenpox is that lesions at different stages of development (papules, vesicles, crusts) can be present simultaneously on the body.

 

O p ghai 9th edition page number 213

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is evaluated for persistent respiratory tract infections and a notable history of abnormal bleeding, exhibiting excessive bleeding from minor injuries. A physical examination also reveals albinism, and an ophthalmological assessment indicates the presence of nystagmus. Laboratory tests, including a CBC, show normal platelet levels, prolonged BT, but normal CT, PT, and aPTT. Given the combination of recurrent infections, albinism, nystagmus, abnormal bleeding, and the specific laboratory findings, which genetic disorder should be suspected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hermansky- Pudlak syndrome

 

Option B:

 

  • The genetic disorder that is likely responsible for the clinical features in this case is Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.
  • It is characterized by albinism, nystagmus, and bleeding tendency due to platelet dysfunction.
  • It is also associated with recurrent infections due to immune dysfunction.
  • Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is caused by mutations in several genes that are involved in the formation and function of lysosomes and related organelles.
  • Treatment may involve antibiotics for infections, medications to control bleeding, and measures to protect the skin and eyes from sun exposure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bernard-Soulier syndrome may also present with similar symptoms but it doesn’t has the presence of pulmonary fibrosis and albinism.

 

Option C. Hemophilia A: This is a clotting factor disorder (factor VIII deficiency) and would typically present with increase aPTT and is not associated with albinism.

 

Option D. Hemophilia B: Also a clotting factor disorder (factor IX deficiency) with similar presentations to Hemophilia A and not associated with albinism or recurrent infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of frequent infections, abnormal bleeding, albinism, and nystagmus suggested Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome. This syndrome's unique constellation of symptoms, including platelet dysfunction without affecting the platelet count or coagulation cascade, sets it apart from other bleeding disorders such as Bernard-Soulier syndrome, Hemophilia A, and Hemophilia B.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition page 3142
